newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Sterling recovers from overnight lows, seen higher.
newsitem.headline: Sterling recovers from overnight lows, seen higher.

text.p: Sterling made a healthy recovery during Asian trade on Thursday after its sharp sell-off in New York overnight, and was seen heading higher in the near term, Singapore dealers said.
The British unit was actively bought from the 1.6140 dollars level in Asia after dropping on a news agency report suggesting the Labour Party supported a weaker sterling.

"There's been a lot of short-covering of sterling and sterling/mark. The investment houses that were selling sterling in New York last night were buying it back this morning and have continued to do so," a European bank dealer said.

Sterling fell more than two cents overnight after a Bridge News report quoted a Labour Party source saying sterling should rejoin Europe's exchange rate mechanism in 2001 at a rate of 2.50 marks, well below its current level of 2.7840.
The U.K. Treasury said there was no truth in the report.
The dealer said the sterling's recovery was helped by the dollar's overall weakness against major currencies on Thursday.

Stop-loss buying orders were triggered from 1.6210 to 1.6250 in cable and from the 2.7820 level upwards on the sterling/mark cross, the dealer said, adding that sterling could easily head back up to 1.6350-1.6400.
"At this stage, the market's just susceptible to comments from politicians and news. They're really waiting to see what the official Labour Party position is on the level of the pound," he said.
